bibl.title: Letter from Lawrence Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 4, 1900

div1.p: Lawrence Reed anticipates his father's return to Cuba. He comments on rumors of reassignment, yellow fever cases, and packages from home.

div1.head: Letter from Lawrence Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 4, 1900
div1.p:
Your usual Sunday
letter did not arrive this morning
so I will look for it Tuesday-

I suppose Father is again
making his plans to return to
Cuba. where as you said
he will remain for a few months.

There have been several
rumors afloat that some
of the troops will be taken
out of Cuba soon but we
put no faith in them, I for
one am too well satisfied
to desire a change at present.

Our coming winter seems from
all appearances to prove a
pleasant one, at present
the days are warm, not hot
and our nights are delightful.

I am so sorry to hear
that Colonel Haskins of the
2d Arty is down with the
yellow fever- He is quite
old and his chance perhaps
are poor-

So far we have had
but two or three cases
in Cienfuegos & they were
in June - and were said to have been
brought from Havana-

I spent a very pleasant evening
last night at Mr & Mrs Waltons, I told
you who they were in my last letter did
I not.? Cooke & I were invited there for
a welsh rarebit, and enjoyed the evening
ever so much-

Mother where are those books
you said you were going to send me-
I have read all the trash I could get
my hands on & do want some good
ones - for I have ample time to devote
to reading -

Well I will write you soon again
when I get your letter - By the way - if you feel
so disposed- send me in care of the Depot Q.M.
Pier 22. Brooklyn- N.Y- such thing as a few pillows for a divan
small rugs & table or trunk cover - or any thing you think
will add to the comfort of my room - also 1/2 doz white gloves.
and 1 doz handkerchiefs - I will pay for them all,
